response:
The subacute progression over 12 days, worsening over the last 3, in a 41-year-old patient favors inflammatory or neoplastic etiologies over hyperacute vascular events. A brainstem glioma or lymphoma could explain the progressive mass effect. Demyelination (MS or NMOSD) is a strong differential given the age and location. Subacute ischaemia or an infectious rhombencephalitis (e.g., Listeria) remain possible.

differential_diagnosis = ["Brainstem Glioma", "Multiple Sclerosis (Demyelination)", "Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD)", "Subacute Pontine Ischaemic Stroke", "Rhombencephalitis (Listeria, HSV)", "Neurosarcoidosis"]
